Biography of the 29th Patriarch of India, Venerable Huike
Venerable Huike was a man from Wulao.
His surname was Ji.
When his mother first became pregnant,
there was a strange light that shone in his family.
And when he was born, for that reason he was named.
When the Venerable was young, he enjoyed studying worldly books.
There was nothing he did not look into.
He was especially good at speaking about Zhuangzi and Laozi.
At the age of thirty, he suddenly felt inspired and sighed, saying:
The Laozi and the Book of Changes are not the ultimate great principles.
So he explored the Buddhist scriptures.
He then traveled far to seek a teacher and arrived at Xiangshan in Luoyang.
He left home under Chan Master Bao Jing.
He then received the precepts at Yongmu Temple.
He left his duties and studied the meaning of the scriptures.
Before long, he understood all the sutras and treatises.
At thirty-two, he returned to his original teacher.
After eight years,
one night a divine person appeared.
He said to the Venerable One,
Why have you stayed here for so long?
You will attain the Way.
You should go south immediately.
The Venerable One encountered the divine being and added the name Shenguang to his name.
The next night, his head suddenly ached unbearably.
The master wanted to cauterize it for him.
Suddenly he heard a voice in the air say,
This is a change of bones, it is not an ordinary pain.
He told his master about it.
The master immediately stopped and did not dare treat it.
When dawn came, he looked at the original bones and found that they had indeed sprouted in five places.
His master said,
This is extraordinary. You will surely have a superior encounter. Go now.
Do not miss the opportunity.
However, his personality was magnanimous and had a far-reaching capacity.
Although he had some comings and goings,
he never spoke rashly.
He mingled and concealed himself naturally.
Thus, he stayed in the capital for a long time, but the world did not know him.
When he met Bodhidharma, who transmitted the Way and changed his name,
he would be the patriarch of the Dharma teachers.
Only then did the learners know that he had great virtue.
They vied to return to him like water rushing down.
